question: They built that train station in 1918. Your father was there the day it opened... He said a tuba band was playing...Oom-pah-pah... Oom-pah-pah, oom-pah-pah...The finest clockmaker in all of the South built that clock...
answer: His name was Mr. Gateau. Mr. Cake. He was married to a Creole of Evangeline Parish and they had a son. Did I mention, Mr. Gateau was from birth, absolutely blind. And when their son came of age, like boys will do, he joined the army. They saw him off at the old train station. Oh how he worked, for months he did nothing but work on the clock for the great train station. One day a letter came...

question: Mr. Gateau, done for the night, went up to his bed.
answer: And their son came home. They buried him where the Gateau family had been buried for a hundred and seven years... Mr. Cake went back to work on his clock... laboring to finish... It was a morning to remember... Papa said there were people everywhere... Even Teddy Roosevelt had come. Mr Cake was never seen again. Some say he died of a broken heart. Some say he went to sea...

question: No, please go call... I hope I haven't disappointed you, Mother.
answer: Oh honey, you could never disappoint me.

question: I wished I had more to show for myself. I know you would have liked to have had grandchildren. My life hasn't been all that... normal... I'm either a step ahead... or a step behind...
answer: What's normal? A hat full of sand.

question: What?
answer: I need my brown suitcase... The envelope...

question: An envelope? This one?
answer: I tried to read it a hundred different times... but I couldn't bring myself...

question: What do you mean?
answer: Read it to me. Just the sound of your voice...

question: I guess not... The air smells sweet...
answer: You look very handsome tonight, Ms. Queenie, handsome as I ever seen you... The green matches your eyes...

question: It isn't everyday a war's over, Mr. Weathers... We have to mark it somehow... You ain't no slouch yourself.
answer: Hambert's back in town... came home legless, but he home... we're gonna throw a party for him... help get himself situated... I know you was sweet on him one time...

question: Sweeter than I shoulda been... Lost his legs you say? "You never know what's comin' for you." She got to stop doing that, or it's diapers for her... I'll be right there, Mrs. Jameson... It sure is nice out here, Mr. Weathers...
answer: Awful nice, Ms. Queenie... Come out back for a moment... take your mind away from things...

question: Just a moment's time...
answer: What in God's name...?!!

question: What is that? A fish crawl out of the river...? God in heaven! My Goodness, the Lord did something here...!
answer: Look like a milk wagon run over it... three times... and back... I didn't see it layin' there... I hope I didn't hurt it none... steppin' on it like that... We best leave it to the police... I'll go --

question: It's for sure nobody wanted to keep it...
answer: Where are you, Queenie...?

question: Hold your water... Go see to them.
answer: Queenie Apple... she went and messed herself all over again...

question: Jane Childress start her a bath... and mind your business, Mrs. Duprey... You'll be messing yourself soon enough too!
answer: Somebody stole my necklace...

question: I'll be right with you, Mrs. Hollister... You may be as ugly as an old pot... but you still a child of God...
answer: Queenie, Apple... she won't go take a bath wit'out you...

question: Mercy, I'll be right there. They're right here, Mrs. Hollister, right 'round your pretty white neck... Come on now...
answer: Dr. Rose has arrived for his visit...

question: ... He's nearly blind from cataracts... I'm not sure he can hear... His bones indicate severe arthritis... His skin has lost all elasticity... His hands and feet are ossified... He has all the deterioration, the infirmities, not of a newborn, but of a man well in his eighties on the way to his grave...
answer: You mean to say he's dying?

question: Of old age. His body is failing him before his life's begun. Where did he come from?
answer: It's my sister's child... From Lafayette. She had an unfortunate adventure. The poor child got the worse of it... came out white...

question: There are places for 'unwanted' babies like these, Queenie... There's no room for another mouth to feed here... The Nolan Foundation, despite their good intentions, thinks this place is a large nuisance as it is... A baby here --
answer: You said he don't have long.

question: Queenie -- some creatures aren't meant to survive.
answer: He is a miracle, that's for certain... just not the kind of miracle one hopes to see... You all listen... We have a visitor that will be staying with us for a little while... My sister had a child but couldn't see right by it... He's known as... Benjamin... Benjamin... He's not a well child... so we need to take very good care of him... He's prematurely old... Doctor Rose said he don't have much time on this earth...

question: How we doin'? What's that say there?
answer: Bis...

question: Biscuits... and...
answer: Graby...

question: Think. That's a 'v' not a 'b.' Say it.
answer: Gravy.

question: Now you talkin'! How many parts butter we got?
answer: Four...

question: How many parts flour?
answer: Two...

question: How much is four and two?
answer: Six.

question: There were birthdays...
answer: And mortality was a common visitor to our house... People came and went... Death was so frequent, I was never afraid of it.

question: You could hear when someone left us... there was a silence in the house...
answer: It was a wonderful place to grow up. I was with people who had put away all the inconsequences of life, left in a state of purely being...wondering about the weather...the temperature of a bath...the light at the end of the day...

question: ...Second wife stepped on viper and dies... It was bad luck to be married to Mr. Oti. I am captured with six others by Baschiele tribe. They sell us to a big white man... The Big White Man brings us to St. Louis, where they make our village at the 1904 World's Fair... They have us livin' in these little huts like we're livin' in Africa... people behind bars staring at us... we told not to look at them... to just go about our normal lives... what the hell they talkin' about... ? At night we're done bein' "savages..." we go over the wall into The Rosebud... we drank and laughed until the sun come up... and then we savages again... I hear you not so old as you looking. You just foolin' everybody. What happen, you get Madjembe?
answer: What's a madjembe?

question: Worms.
answer: I don't think so. This is just how I am.

question: You want to get a cold root beer?
answer: It's dangerous.

question: Who said that? ...Come on little man... Hurry... ...Another white man come to my country and say he want to talk to me... Then I am in the monkey house at "Philadelphia Zoological Park." Three thousand people show up my first day...
answer: What's it like living in a cage?

question: It stinks. The monkeys, they do some tricks... I throw spear... I wrestle with Kowali, she is orangutan... They have me file my teeth like a cannibal... When I'm not playing with monkeys - - they want me to run to bars in my cage with teeth to scare little children...
answer: Why didn't you go back home?

question: War between English and Dutch people had broken up kingdom.
answer: What did you do?

question: I leave zoo. Go here. Go there. Everything okay. But I alone.
answer: You were all alone?

question: No, that's fine...please...
answer: Was there just company?

question: Dorothy had to go home...
answer: Caroline...

question: Are you sleeping? Come on...
answer: Where are we going?

question: Under here... Nobody knows about this but us. Will you light it?
answer: I'm not supposed to use matches...

question: Don't be chicken... I'll tell you a secret then you tell me one... I saw mommy kissing another man. Her face was red from it. Your turn to tell.
answer: I'm younger than I look.

question: You don't seem like an old person... like my grandma... Are you sick?
answer: I heard Tizzy and my mother whisper. They said I was going to die soon. But I fooled them so far.

question: I come to say goodbye. I'm going away.
answer: Going away? Where?

question: I don't figure that out yet. I will send you a postcard when I get to there.
answer: What about your friend? The tall lady?

question: We're not friends anymore. That's what happens with tall people.
answer: Goodbye...

question: Are all you afraid of workin' for a livin'? Somebody got to want a job...
answer: I do...!

question: You got your sea legs old man?
answer: I do. I think.

question: ... What were you born to do, old timer?
answer: I haven't found out yet.

question: You haven't found out yet?! How old are you, Benjamin, seventy somethin' or other?
answer: Not as old as I look.

question: Tha's a good one..." You older than Hades you creaky old bastard! What the hell you been doing with your life?
answer: It's a short story...

question: Can you still get it up?
answer: I do every morning.

question: The old pole? The hard'n? Can you still get it up?
answer: I guess.

question: When was the last time you had a woman, you creaky old bastard...?
answer: Never.

question: Never!
answer: Not that I know of.

question: You been on this earth for more than seventy years and you never got any?! That's the saddest thing I ever heard in my life. Never?
answer: Never.

question: You din't say? What did your father do?
answer: I never met my father.

question: You're a lucky bastard! All father's want to do is hold you down!.. Out on my father's boat, working da two-a-days... This littl' fat bastard, "tug Irish," what they calls them. They say the Irish the only one's stupid `nough to work a tug. Them and the Portuguese, as we all know how stupid them Portuguese is. I fin'ly get up the nerves and tell him... "I don't wanta spend da rest of my life on a goddamn tugboat...!" You know what I'm sayin'?
answer: You didn't want to spend the rest of your life on a tugboat.

question: Absolutely, damn right! So you know what my father says? He says "Who the hell you think you are?" "What the hell you think you can do?" I tell him. "Well if you askin' -- I want to be a artist." He laughs. He says, "If God wanted you to be an artist he would made you one." "God wanted you to work a tugboat just like me, and that's what you goin' to do?" "Now, if I ever hear you mention art again, I'll throw you overboard!" Well, I went and I show him... I made myself an artist... A tattoos artist...! I puts every one on myself! You have to skin me alive to take my art away from me now! When I'm dead I'm going to send him my arm! Don't let anyone tell you different! You got to do what you meant to do! And I happen to be a god-damned artist!
answer: But you're a tugboat captain.

question: How are you tonight, Grandpa? Clean yourself up...
answer: Is that any better?

question: Let's go... Time's a wastin'...
answer: Ohhh...!

question: Come by anytime...
answer: Again?

question: Again? My hat's off to you old timer.
answer: Again?

question: Again? What are you, Dick Tracy or something? I've got to rest...
answer: Again? Thank you...

question: No, thank you... Have a nice night...
answer: You'll be here tomorrow?

question: It's awful wet out. Can I offer you a ride somewhere...?
answer: That's very kind of you, Sir.

question: My name is Thomas, Thomas Button.
answer: I'm Benjamin.

question: Benjamin... Yes, Benjamin... It's a pleasure to know you. Would you like to stop and have a drink, Benjamin?
answer: I'll have whatever he's having.

question: A Sazerac for both of us...with whiskey instead of brandy... You don't drink do you?
answer: It's a night for firsts...

question: How is that?
answer: I've never been to a whore house either.

question: It's an... experience...
answer: It certainly is. I'm not very experienced about a lot of things.

question: That isn't a bad thing.
answer: There's a first time for everything.

question: True enough. I don't mean to be rude... but your hands seem awful bent... It must be quite painful?
answer: I don't really know what I have. I have some form of a disease. I have a lot of catching up to do.

question: What kind of a disease?
answer: I was born old.

question: I'm sorry.
answer: No need to be. Nothing wrong with old age.

question: I'm sorry about your disease.
answer: My mother says we're all born with something...

question: Your mother?
answer: I'm adopted.

question: ... My wife passed away many years ago...
answer: I'm very sorry.

question: She died in childbirth. To children.
answer: To mothers and fathers... What line of work are you in, Mr. Button?

question: Buttons. "Button's Buttons." There isn't a button we don't make. Our biggest competition is B.F. Goodrich and his infernal zippers... One more Benjamin?
answer: If you'll let me pay for it, Mr. Button...

question: What kind of work do you do?
answer: I'm a tugboat man.

question: I enjoyed talking to you...
answer: I enjoyed drinking with you...

question: Benjamin... Would you mind, if time to time, I stopped by to say hello...?
answer: Anytime.

question: Goodnight, Benjamin.
answer: Absolutely... Mr. Button... I listened to some music.... I -- I met some people. I think mama... I'm going to...

question: Do you want to see something? We have to keep it secret. Get dressed. I'll meet you behind the kitchen... Ssssh... Can you swim?
answer: I can do anything you can do...

question: Put this on... We have to go fast...
answer: What's wrong with him?

question: I think he has mejembe. Captain Mike... could you take us out?
answer: You know what day it is?

question: Sunday.
answer: Do you know what dat mean? It means I was very drunk last night.

question: You're drunk every night.
answer: Is that a girl?

question: A close friend... I wanted to show her the River.
answer: I'm not supposed to be joy-ridin' with civilians... I could lose my license. What you standin' there for! She put in for repair... a wounded duck... She's flyin' now...

question: Imagine all the places they're going to see... I wish we could go with them... I wish we could have...
answer: Did you say something, Mother? It seems to be getting worse. Are you hearing me, mother?

question: Look at that... time just seeped out of me...
answer: What?

question: Somebody will come and mop it up and that will be the end...
answer: Do you want me to go on reading? "Things were changing quickly."

question: I think I should find out what's going on...
answer: There's a box of them... in a velvet bag...

question: Is this what you're looking for?
answer: Looking for?

question: You said you wanted this?
answer: Of course. Can you imagine... He sent me postcards from everywhere he went... every place he worked... Newfoundland... Baffin Bay... Liverpool... Glasgow...Narvik... Please keep reading, sugar...

question: Her name was Elizabeth Abbott. She was not beautiful. She was plain as paper... But she was as pretty as any picture to me...
answer: What are you looking at? If you must know, we have a long standing agreement never to go to bed sober. Isn't that right darling?

question: Her husband was Walter Abbott...He was Chief Minister of the British Trade Mission in Murmansk... and he was a spy...
answer: I broke the heel off of one of my shoes...I don't usually walk around in my bare feet...

question: I'm sorry... I can't sleep... I was going to make some tea...would you like some? Milk...? Honey...?
answer: Some honey, thank you.

question: Do you like flies with your tea?
answer: You must let it steep for a minute...

question: Steep?
answer: Sit. There's a proper way to make tea.

question: Where I'm from, they just want it to be hot.
answer: You're a seaman? I don't mean to be rude...but aren't you rather old to be working on a boat?

question: There's no age limit... as long as you can do the work...
answer: You have trouble sleeping?

question: I didn't know I did... I usually sleep like a baby. Something kept me up.
answer: I never sleep... Well, rarely anyway... My father, when he was in his eighties, was so sure he was going to die in his sleep... He would only take naps during the afternoon... so that death couldn't catch him...

question: Did he?
answer: Did he what?

question: Die in his sleep?
answer: He died sitting in his favorite chair listening to his favorite program on the radio.

question: He must have known something.
answer: My husband's the British Trade Minister. We've been here fourteen months... We were supposed to be going to Peking... but it just never did work out. It never does seem to work out. Have you been to the Far East?

question: I haven't really been anywhere. I mean outside different harbors.
answer: Where are you from?

question: New Orleans, Louisiana.
answer: I didn't know there was another one. I've never been to America. Everywhere else. But not America. Am I missing anything?

question: And she told me all the places she had been, and what she had seen...
answer: I can tell you what bars look like in places all over the world...

question: And we talked until just before the dawn...
answer: Thank you for the tea...

question: ...And we went back to our rooms... to our separate lives... And every night... we would meet in the middle Of the night... A hotel in the middle of the night can be a magical place... A mouse stopping and running and stopping... A radiator hissing. A sink dripping. A floor creaking. A curtain blowing. There is something peaceful, even comforting, knowing that people you love are asleep in their beds, where nothing can harm them... Elizabeth and I would talk through the night until just before dawn...
answer: I may have given you the wrong impression.

question: I may have given you the wrong impression.
answer: The wrong impression?

question: You must think I don't love my husband.
answer: Why do you say that?

question: Married women don't usually sit with strange men in a hotel in the middle of the night. I certainly don't.
answer: I don't know what married women do or don't do.

question: Do I look okay? I borrowed it from one of the men. It's his church suit.
answer: You take my breath away. The thing about clothing is, it should make you feel comfortable, then you will be comfortable... Come, let's take a walk...

question: I feel so much younger when I'm with you...
answer: That's such a nice thing to say. You make me feel years younger, too. I wish I was. I would change so many things. I would undo all of my mistakes.

question: What mistakes?
answer: I kept waiting, thinking I would do something to change my circumstance... Do something... But I never did... It's an awful waste, you can never get it back... wasted time... If we're going to have an affair, you're never to look at me during the day, we must always part by sunrise, and we can never say "I love you..." And when it is over I will send you a card that will simply say goodbye... Those are the rules...

question: Are you as cold as I am?
answer: My god, colder. You can't even break a bottle here. Get a key.

question: Roosevelt says we all got to do our part! After them Japs attacked Pearl Harbor everyone's got to! The Chelsea's been commissioned to serve in the United States Navy, to repair, tow, salvage and rescue... Anybody don't want to go to war, now's the time to say so... Once you set foot on that boat again, you're in the Navy friend!
answer: I'll go captain!

question: Easy old timer. I'll hold it against no man. But speak up now or forever hold your water. You're free to get home any way you can Mr. Mayes.
answer: I grew up cooking, sir. I'll take the job, if I'm not too old to serve.

question: There's a shit load of things you don't know... You look like you've been born again... you're younger than the springtime... I think that preacher laid the hands on you brought you a second life... I knew the moment I saw you -- you were special... Every night I got on my knees asking the Good Lord to bring you back safely. Remember what I told you...?
answer: You never know what's comin' for you.

question: Did you learn anything worth repeating?
answer: I saw a lot of things.

question: You seen some pain. Some joy too?
answer: Where's Tizzy?

question: Mr. Weathers died in his sleep one night last April. He's sleeping comfortably now in the cemetery on St. James street, God rest his soul...
answer: I'm so sorry...

question: Oh, excuse me... is Queenie here...?
answer: Daisy... it's me, Benjamin.

question: Benjamin...Oh my God it's you... Of course it's you... Benjamin, how are you? It's been such a long time... There's so much I want to know... When did you come back?
answer: Just a few weeks ago...

question: I spoke to Queenie...she told me you were in the war...somewhere at sea... I was so worried about you...
answer: I'm okay. I can't get over you -- You are so lovely...

question: You stopped writing.
answer: I feel terrible about it... Now that I see you I feel even worse... Look at you...Daisy Fuller...

question: I can't get over you're home... I've been planning to come by for awhile... my grandmother, you remember Grandma Fuller... of course you remember her... she passed away...
answer: I heard that... I'm sorry...

question: I've been wanting to get some of her things... I can't believe I open the door, and you're actually standing there...It must be fate... What do they call it, "Kismet"? I read a book about a man named Edgar Cayce, a psychic, everything is predetermined...I like to think it's fate. What do you think, Benjamin?
answer: I don't know how it works, but I'm sure glad it happened...

question: Have you been to New York...? It's just across the bridge from me... I can actually see the Empire State Building if I stand on my bed... Where have you been? Tell me everything. The last time you wrote you said you were in Russia? I always wanted to go to Russia... Is it as cold as they say...? You wrote you met somebody... did it work out...?
answer: Remember this?

question: ...This is the picture of Old Man Kangaroo at five in the afternoon..." You don't look like an old man anymore...You always said you were different... I think you must be...
answer: Are you hungry? Would you like to get something to eat?

question: I would love that... They understand America's vigor and physicality -- they understand the freshness of the American people at their most modern, at their best. Oh my god, I've been just talking about myself...
answer: I'm enjoying listening... I didn't know you smoked...

question: I'm old enough. I`m old enough for a lot of things....
answer: Yes you are...

question: I have to go back tomorrow... I wish I could stay... In New York we stay up all night... I eat breakfast in a diner on Houston with red booths and watch the sun come up over the buildings... there's always something to do... Dancers... don't need costumes or scenery. I could imagine dancing completely naked... Have you read "D.H. Lawrence," his books were banned... The words are like making love.... In our group... you have to trust people... not be afraid... Sex... is a big part of it... A lot of the dancers... are lesbians... A woman wanted me to sleep with her.... Does that upset you?
answer: Which part?

question: That someone wanted to sleep with me.
answer: People should want to sleep with you... You're very desirable...

question: Let's go back to the house... or get a room somewhere... we can put down your coat...
answer: It's not that I don't want to... I just can't... not tonight....Its just not...

question: I'm old enough.
answer: Go back to New York, Daisy... Be with the people you are so fond of... You can only be young once...

question: Oh, that's great. Isn't that good news, Mother?
answer: Good news?

question: The hurricane. It is going to miss us.
answer: I'll just stay under the blankets with my mother. She said nothing would happen to me. Benjamin?

question: Hello, Benjamin... Do you remember me?
answer: Of course, Mr. Button... What happened to you?

question: My foot was infected... I'm afraid they had to remove it... Welcome home, my friend.
answer: You're still drinking Sazerac with whiskey instead of brandy.

question: I'm a man of habit.
answer: Are you still visiting the house on Bourbon street?

question: Not for a long time. The war has been kind to the button industry... we had gone from making forty thousand buttons a day to making two hundred and fifty thousand... We employed ten times the number of workers... We were operating around the clock... I don't know how much longer I have to live...
answer: I'm sorry to hear that, Mr. Button.

question: I don't have any people. I keep to myself. I -- I'm frightened. I hope you won't mind... but whenever it's possible... I would enjoy your company...
answer: I'll do what I can, Mr. Button.

question: Tell me Benjamin, do you know anything about buttons?
answer: Just what holds my shirt on.

question: ... comes from the French, "bouton," meaning a bud, or any round object... They were originally decorative, jewelry sewn on clothing... The practice of buttoning originated in the 13th century... when baggy clothing was replaced with more form-fitting clothes... Button's Buttons has been in our family for one hundred and twenty- four years. My grandfather was a tailor. He had a small shop in Richmond. After the Civil War he came to New Orleans. My father saw the wisdom of making our own buttons. The tailor shop grew to this... And today... I can't sew a stitch.
answer: It's all very interesting. But what do you want from me?

question: I said, our family has been in the business for a hundred and twenty- four years.
answer: Our family?

question: You are my family. Benjamin, you are my son. I am so sorry not to have told you before... You were born the night the great war ended... Your mother died giving birth to you... I thought... I thought you were a monster... I left you on the back steps of a house... I promised your mother I'd make sure you were safe... I should never have abandoned you...
answer: My mother?

question: ...A great uncle, from Germany. All of the men in the family at the Lake House... 1915, three years before you were born. Your grandfather at the summer house on Lake Pontchartrain. When I was a boy I would love to wake up before anybody else and run down to the lake to watch the day begin. It was as if I was the only one alive. I fell in love with her the first time I saw her. Your mother's name was Caroline Murphy. She was 20. She worked in your grandfather's kitchen...She was from Dublin... Her father, your maternal grandfather, was a chimney sweep... He died in the flu epidemic of 1900... Caroline came with her mother, two sisters, and four brothers in 1903 to live in New Orleans. I would find reasons to go to the kitchen... just to look at her... The happiest day of my life was April 25th, 1918 the day I married your mother.
answer: Why didn't you tell me?

question: I made a mistake. Come and take your rightful place... with your family... with me... We can catch up for all the lost time... I'm planning on leaving everything I have to you...
answer: I better go.

question: Where are you going?
answer: Home.

question: Somebody's looking for me?... Benjamin... What are you doing here?
answer: I thought I'd come visit... spend some time with you if I could...

question: I wish you would have called... You caught me by surprise.
answer: I couldn't take my eyes off of you... you were mesmerizing...

question: That's so nice of you to say... These are lovely... Thank you... I better get changed... a group of us are going to a party... would you like to come...?
answer: Somebody told me about a restaurant I thought you might enjoy... I made a reservation... Just in case --

question: He came to tell me his father had died.
answer: You couldn't have known.

question: I was 23...I just didn't care... ...There are some photographs I think... the zipper part of the large bag...
answer: I've never seen these... You never talked about your dancing very much...

question: Hello, Daisy...
answer: Who told you?

question: Your friend wired me.
answer: That was very kind of you... to come all the way here, to see that I was alright.

question: You would have done the same for me...
answer: My God, look at you. You're perfect.... I wish you hadn't. I wish you hadn't come here. I don't want you to see me like this...

question: I'll get a room... and once you can leave you'll come home with me to New Orleans. Where you can be with people who love you.
answer: What home? Who's we? I'm not going back to New Orleans. New Orleans is your home... I don't have a home... I haven't been home for five years... I'm not going anywhere with you...

question: Alright, I'll stay here in Paris... I'll help you with anything you need...
answer: Benjamin...! I know I'm feeling sorry for myself... But it wasn't supposed to be like this... Do you understand, I don't want to be with you... I tried to tell you that in New York... You just don't listen...

question: You'll change your mind.
answer: We're not little children playing under the table... Remember, when you came to New York. You didn't belong there. I didn't want to be with you then, I don't want to be with you now! I want you to leave! I'm not going anywhere with you! I want you to stay out of my life! I was awfully cruel. He didn't understand. I couldn't have him see me that way...

question: She's still taking care of you. You're not talking. You haven't said more than two words to me.
answer: I don't want to ruin it... Goodnight.

question: Sleep with me.
answer: Are you sure?

question: Yes. Are you sure you don't want to know?... I lived in Lyon... ...I learned to walk again ...I worked in a flower shop... ...I went to American movies a lot. You won't hurt me... We wouldn't have this... We wouldn't be here... It happened when it was supposed to happen...
answer: Relationships have a time and a place.

question: Don't say that.
answer: What I mean is... You don't usually get more than one chance. If you miss it, it's too late... and it's gone... We're lucky... we had more than one chance.

question: That's easy for you to say... You'll have plenty of chances. I'm going to enjoy every moment I have with you...
answer: Have you ever had a Sazerac with whiskey not brandy?

question: Bet I can stay out here longer than you can.
answer: Bet you can't.

question: You barely have a line, a crease, or a wrinkle... Everyday I have more wrinkles you have less...
answer: I love your wrinkles.

question: What does it feel like growing younger?
answer: I don't know... I'm always looking out of my own eyes...

question: Will you still love me when I can't stand straight... when my skin grows old and spotted... Will you still love me when my step gets slow... when I sleep too much... when you have to push me in a chair...
answer: Will you still love me when I have pimples. When I think it's funny to make fart noises... Will you still love me when I think all girls have cooties... Will you still love me when I wet my bed at night... Will you still love me when I'm afraid of things that aren't real... Nothing lasts...

question: Maybe some things last...
answer: I've never seen anything not come to an end...

question: Caroline?
answer: I don't understand. When did you meet Dad?

question: Dear Robert... some time after that...
answer: Did you ever tell him about this Benjamin?

question: He knew enough. He loved me as I was. I loved him for who he was. What more was needed?
answer: "That night, in the Caribbean I had a visitor..."

question: I thought I was far too old... I'm pregnant...
answer: You were pregnant? You never said anything, did you? I mean, what happened to the child?

question: The child...
answer: They said if you needed oxygen...

question: I want to breathe on my own... Please... sit down, my darling... I'm pregnant.
answer: "She flourished..."

question: Hmmm... I thought I heard the nurse slip, and say "he..." I know you're afraid.
answer: I'm not hiding it.

question: Okay. What's your worst fear?
answer: What if it has...what if its like me?...

question: Then we'll love it all the more...
answer: I want to be father... not a little brother... I don't want to be picked up from elementary school by my kid... I don't want anyone babysitting me...

question: I'm going to make this work... This is what I want, and I want it with you...
answer: You know, there's nothing I wouldn't do for you...

question: Don't eat sand... She's going to have a really attractive diaper. I think you should find a real father for her...
answer: What are you talking about?

question: She needs someone to grow old with...
answer: She'll learn to accept whatever happens... She loves you...

question: She needs a father not a playmate.
answer: Is it that my age is starting to show...? Is that what you are telling me? Have you lost your desire for me...?

question: You don't need another child to raise...
answer: You're going to leave me, aren't you? You can't leave me. You can't do this to me...!

question: This is a friend of my family's... Benjamin Button... this is my husband... Robert... I'm just closing up...
answer: She's so lovely... she looks like you... Does she dance?

question: Not very well.
answer: I suppose that would be from my side of things.

question: My husband. He's a doctor... was a widower... He's an incredibly bright, adventurous man... He's been a terrific father... and a great partner and friend... You're so much younger.
answer: Just what you can see.

question: You ware right. She needed a father. I couldn't have raised both of you. I'm not that strong. I never thought how it must have broken your heart, too. Where are you staying? What are you going to do?
answer: I'm at the Pontchartrain Hotel on the avenue. I have no idea what I'm going to do.

question: Hello?
answer: May I come in?

question: Please... I don't know what I'm doing here...What I expected...?
answer: Nothing lasts.

question: I never once stopped loving you...
answer: I'm an old woman now, Benjamin. Benjamin... Are you sure?

question: Some things you don't ever forget... the feel... the taste... ... the smell... ... the touch... Of someone you love...
answer: Please read...

question: A year or so after your father passed... There was a call... Hello?... Yes?... Speaking -- I don't understand? Where was that? It's the last house... I'm Daisy...
answer: Thank you for coming... I'm David Hernandez with the Orleans Parish department of Child Welfare Services. He was found living in a condemned building off of east Lamont... the police found this with him... this address... and your name... He was in very poor health... he was taken to the hospital... He doesn't seem to know who or where he is... He's very confused... The doctors who looked at him think he may be autistic.

question: Benjamin. You play really beautifully.
answer: He doesn't seem to like to be touched. The doctors said if they didn't know any better, he goes in and out of states of recognition, as if he had the beginnings of dementia...

question: Do you remember me? I'm Daisy. It's good to meet you Benjamin. Do you mind if I sit with you? I would love to hear you play. Queenie's daughter saw to it that he was taken care of...
answer: I want some breakfast. No I didn't... You think I don't know what you are doing? You are all fucking liars!

question: Let's see if we can find something else for you to do.
answer: I can't help it. I can't help this.

question: I know you can't.
answer: I get the feeling there's a lot of things I can't remember...

question: What do you mean?
answer: It's like there's this whole life I had and I can't remember what it was...
